items.label: Identification and Scope
items.description:
Clearly state whether the study involves the development or evaluation of a multivariable prediction model, AI/ML-based system, or other interventions.
Indicate the target population, intended use, and the outcome to be predicted or evaluated.

items.label: Study Type and Objectives
items.description:
Specify the type of study (e.g., systematic review, diagnostic accuracy study, clinical evaluation).
Highlight the primary objectives and intended users (e.g., healthcare professionals, patients).

items.label: Evaluation Metrics
items.description: Mention key evaluation metrics such as sensitivity, specificity, predictive values, AUC, and any other relevant performance measures.

items.label: Structured Summary
items.description: Provide a structured summary that clearly outlines the background, objectives, methods, results, and conclusions of the study. This ensures all key aspects of the study are concisely presented.

items.label: Objectives and Implications
items.description: Highlight the study objectives and the implications of the findings for practice. This helps in understanding the practical impact and relevance of the study.

items.label: Scientific Background
items.description: Provide a detailed scientific background that outlines the current state of knowledge in the field, including key findings from existing research.

items.label: Rationale for the Study
items.description: Clearly explain the rationale for conducting the study, highlighting the gap in knowledge or the specific problem the study aims to address.

items.label: Study Objectives
items.description: State the specific objectives of the study, detailing what the study aims to achieve and its potential impact on the field.

items.label: Study Design
items.description: Provide a detailed description of the study design, including the type of study (e.g., randomized controlled trial, cohort study, case-control study), the setting, and the time frame.

items.label: Data Sources and Collection
items.description: Describe the sources of data used in the study, the methods for data collection, and any tools or software used for data acquisition.

items.label: Participant Selection
items.description: Detail the criteria for participant selection, including inclusion and exclusion criteria, the recruitment process, and the number of participants.

items.label: Interventions and Comparisons
items.description: Explain the interventions or exposures being studied, any control or comparison groups, and the procedures for implementing these interventions.

items.label: Outcome Measures
items.description: Define the primary and secondary outcomes of the study, including how and when these outcomes are assessed.

items.label: Statistical Analysis
items.description: Provide a comprehensive plan for statistical analysis, including the methods used to analyze the data, any adjustments for confounding variables, and the software or tools used for analysis.

items.label: Blinding and Randomization (if applicable)
items.description: Describe the methods used for randomization and blinding, if applicable, to ensure the validity and reliability of the study results.

items.label: Ethical Considerations
items.description: Include information on ethical approval and consent processes, ensuring the study adheres to ethical guidelines and standards.

items.label: Participant Flow and Demographics
items.description: Detail the flow of participants through the study, including the number of participants at each stage (enrollment, intervention allocation, follow-up, and analysis). Provide baseline demographic and clinical characteristics of the participants.

items.label: Primary and Secondary Outcomes
items.description: Present the primary and secondary outcomes of the study, including effect estimates and confidence intervals. Highlight any statistically significant findings and their clinical relevance.

items.label: Adverse Events
items.description: Report any adverse events or unintended effects that occurred during the study, including their frequency and severity.

items.label: Statistical Analysis and Significance
items.description: Provide the results of the statistical analyses, including p-values, confidence intervals, and any adjustments for confounding variables. Summarize the key findings in a clear and concise manner.

items.label: Subgroup Analyses (if applicable)
items.description: Include any relevant subgroup analyses, explaining how these subgroups were defined and the results of these analyses.

items.label: Model Performance (for predictive models)
items.description: For studies involving predictive models, report the performance measures of the model, such as discrimination (e.g., area under the curve), calibration, and validation results.

items.label: Interpretation of Results
items.description: Provide a clear interpretation of the study findings, discussing how the results contribute to the existing body of knowledge and their relevance to clinical practice.

items.label: Comparison with Existing Literature
items.description: Compare the study findings with those from previous research, highlighting similarities, differences, and possible reasons for any discrepancies.

items.label: Study Limitations
items.description: Acknowledge the limitations of the study, including potential biases, methodological constraints, and any issues with generalizability.

items.label: Implications for Practice
items.description: Discuss the practical implications of the study findings for clinical practice, policy-making, or healthcare delivery. Include any recommendations for changes in practice based on the results.

items.label: Recommendations for Future Research
items.description: Suggest areas for future research, including unanswered questions, potential improvements in study design, and new directions for investigation.

items.label: Generalizability
items.description: Address the generalizability of the study findings, considering the study population, setting, and methods used.

items.label: Strengths and Weaknesses
items.description: Summarize the strengths and weaknesses of the study, providing a balanced view of the study's contribution and its limitations.

items.label: Summary of Main Findings
items.description: Provide a clear and concise summary of the study's primary outcomes, highlighting the most significant results.

items.label: Clinical and Practical Implications
items.description: Discuss the practical and clinical implications of the findings, including how they can be applied in clinical practice, policy-making, or healthcare delivery.

items.label: Funding
items.description: Detail the sources of funding for the study and describe the role of the funders in the research process.

items.label: Conflicts of Interest
items.description: Disclose any potential conflicts of interest that could influence the study's outcomes or interpretation.

items.label: Ethical Approval
items.description: Provide information about the ethical approvals obtained for the study, including the name of the ethical review board or committee.

items.label: Data Sharing and Availability
items.description: State the policies regarding the availability and sharing of the data used in the study, including any repositories where the data can be accessed.

items.label: Protocol Registration
items.description: Include details of the registration of the study protocol, such as the registry name and registration number.

items.label: Author Contributions
items.description: Specify the contributions of each author to the study, ensuring transparency in roles and responsibilities.

items.label: Acknowledgements
items.description: Mention any acknowledgements for individuals or organizations that contributed to the study but are not listed as authors.

items.label: Study Type and Purpose
items.description: Clearly identify the study as developing, evaluating, validating, or updating an AI-based tool or method in healthcare. Include the specific type of study (e.g., randomized trial, diagnostic accuracy study, systematic review).

items.label: Target Population and Clinical Context
items.description: Describe the target population, the clinical setting, and the rationale for selecting this population and setting. Provide a background on why the AI technology or method is relevant and necessary in this context.

items.label: Objectives and Hypotheses
items.description: State the specific objectives or hypotheses of the study. Explain the intended purpose and expected outcomes of the AI technology or method being evaluated or developed.

items.label: Study Design and Methods
items.description: Provide a structured overview of the study design, including the type of study (e.g., randomized trial, diagnostic accuracy study, systematic review), participant demographics, data sources, and specific AI methods used.

items.label: Key Outcomes and Results
items.description: Summarize the primary outcomes measured, key results, and the number of participants analyzed. Include the AI tool's performance metrics, diagnostic accuracy, or validation results.

items.label: Conclusions
items.description: Present the main conclusions of the study, emphasizing the implications of the AI technology or method in the clinical context. Discuss the relevance of the findings and any potential impact on healthcare practice.

items.label: Background
items.description: Explain the scientific, healthcare, or technological context that necessitates the study. This includes the current state of research, existing evidence, and gaps that the AI study aims to fill. Emphasize the relevance and importance of the AI technology in addressing specific problems or improving outcomes.

items.label: Objectives
items.description: Clearly articulate the primary objectives, goals, and hypotheses of the study. This includes specifying whether the study involves development, validation, or evaluation of an AI tool or method. Highlight the intended purpose, expected contributions, and any specific research questions the study aims to answer.

items.label: Study Design 1
items.description: Describe the type of study design used, including details of the setting (e.g., healthcare, clinical trial, observational study). Outline the rationale for choosing this design and how it aligns with the study objectives. Include specifics about the participant selection, intervention (if applicable), and any control or comparison groups.

items.label: Study Design 2
items.description: Specify the sources of data for development and evaluation datasets, representativeness, and key elements of the study setting.

items.label: Data Collection
items.description: Detail the timing of data collection (prospective vs. retrospective), eligibility criteria, basis for identifying participants, setting and timing of identification, and participant series (e.g., consecutive, random, convenience).

items.label: Test Methods
items.description: Explain the details of the index test and reference standard, rationale for choosing the reference standard, and definitions and rationale for test positivity cut-offs or result categories.

items.label: Data Preparation
items.description: Describe any data pre-processing and quality checking procedures.

items.label: Outcome and Predictors
items.description: Define the outcome being predicted and the time horizon. Define all predictors used in the development of the prediction model, including how and when they were measured.

items.label: Model Development
items.description: Describe how the models were developed, specify any software used, and provide the development methods.

items.label: Model Validation
items.description: Describe how the prediction model was validated and assessed.

items.label: Analysis
items.description: Detail the methods for estimating or comparing measures of diagnostic accuracy, handling indeterminate results, handling missing data, analyses of variability in diagnostic accuracy, and sample size determination.

items.label: Data Management Plans
items.description: Outline the procedures for data entry, including the methods and tools used for capturing data accurately. Detail the coding processes applied to the data, ensuring consistency and standardization.

items.label: Data Security and Storage
items.description: Describe the security measures in place to protect data, such as encryption, access controls, and regular audits. Include plans for secure storage of data, both physically and electronically, to prevent unauthorized access and data breaches.

items.label: Data Quality Assurance
items.description: Specify the processes implemented to promote data quality, such as validation checks, data cleaning protocols, and regular quality audits. Include any training provided to personnel involved in data handling to ensure adherence to these standards.

items.label: Model Architecture
items.description: Provide a comprehensive description of the AI model's architecture, including the type of model, the layers, the number of parameters, and any special configurations or features.

items.label: Training Data
items.description: Detail the dataset used for training the model, including the source of the data, the size of the dataset, and any preprocessing steps applied. Discuss the representativeness of the training data and any efforts made to ensure it covers the relevant population.

items.label: Evaluation Metrics
items.description: Specify the metrics used to evaluate the model's performance, such as accuracy, precision, recall, F1 score, and AUC-ROC. Include details on how these metrics were calculated and the rationale behind their selection.

items.label: Estimation Methods
items.description: Outline the methods used for estimating or comparing measures of diagnostic accuracy. This includes the statistical techniques and models employed to assess the performance of the AI system.

items.label: Handling Indeterminate Results
items.description: Describe the approach taken to handle indeterminate results from the index test or reference standard. Explain the criteria for categorizing results as indeterminate and the subsequent steps taken in the analysis.

items.label: Handling Missing Data
items.description: Detail the strategies used to manage missing data on the index test and reference standard. Include any imputation techniques, exclusion criteria, and the impact of missing data on the analysis.

items.label: Sample Size Determination
items.description: Specify the intended sample size for the study and the rationale behind its determination. Include any statistical calculations or power analyses conducted to justify the sample size.

items.label: Participant Flow
items.description: Illustrate the flow of participants through the study using a diagram. This should detail the number of participants at each stage, including recruitment, enrollment, follow-up, and analysis phases.

items.label: Baseline Characteristics
items.description: Present the baseline demographic and clinical characteristics of the study participants. This includes age, gender, relevant medical history, and any other pertinent information that describes the study population.

items.label: Results of the AI Intervention
items.description: Provide detailed results of the AI intervention, including any performance metrics. Compare the AI intervention results to standard methods, highlighting any improvements, equivalences, or deficiencies. Include statistical measures such as accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and other relevant metrics.

items.label: Interpretation of Findings
items.description: Provide an interpretation of the study results, discussing their significance and implications for clinical practice or future research. Highlight any limitations and how they might impact the findings.

items.label: Comparison with Existing Studies
items.description: Compare the study results with existing studies or evidence in the field. Discuss any similarities or differences and potential reasons for these.

items.label: Implications for Practice
items.description: Discuss the practical implications of the findings for clinical practice or policy. Explain how the AI technology or method could be integrated into healthcare settings and its potential benefits.

items.label: Future Research Directions
items.description: Suggest directions for future research, including any unanswered questions or new avenues of investigation that arise from the study findings.

items.label: Research Ethics Approval
items.description: Detail the plans for seeking approval from a research ethics committee or institutional review board (REC/IRB). This includes the process and expected timeline for obtaining ethical clearance.

items.label: Consent or Assent
items.description: Describe who will obtain informed consent or assent from potential trial participants or authorized surrogates, and the process by which this will be done. Ensure that the process is clear, respectful, and adheres to ethical guidelines.

items.label: Confidentiality
items.description: Explain how personal information about potential and enrolled participants will be collected, shared, and maintained to protect confidentiality before, during, and after the trial. This includes data encryption, anonymization, and secure storage protocols.

items.label: Declaration of Interests
items.description: Disclose any financial and other competing interests for principal investigators for the overall trial and each study site. This ensures transparency and addresses potential conflicts of interest.

items.label: Access to Data
items.description: Provide a statement about who will have access to the final trial dataset and disclose any contractual agreements that might limit such access for investigators. This promotes transparency and enables independent verification of the results.

items.label: User Engagement
items.description: Detail the involvement of end-users in the design and development of the AI tool. This includes methods for gathering user feedback, iterative design processes, and ensuring that user needs and preferences are considered throughout the development lifecycle.

items.label: Usability Testing
items.description: Describe the design and implementation of usability studies. This includes the methodology for testing the AI tool's ease of use, user satisfaction, and any modifications made based on usability testing results. Ensure that the usability study is well-structured and includes a diverse range of participants to comprehensively evaluate the tool's performance in real-world settings.

items.label: Data Availability
items.description: Clearly disclose whether and how the relevant data and code used in the study are available. Provide details on any repositories or platforms where the data and code can be accessed, including any conditions or restrictions on access.

items.label: Data Sharing
items.description: Outline the plans for data sharing and availability. This includes specifying what data will be shared, with whom, and under what conditions. Ensure transparency about any limitations on data sharing, and provide mechanisms for other researchers to access the data to verify findings or conduct further research.
